div.stage: Enter above Ormandine, his friends, Tarpax, and spirits.

sp.speaker: Orm.
sp.l: He's now within a mile and less of us;
Spirits away, each fall unto his task,
Whilst I raise storms which may dismay the knight.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Yonder's the place, mine eye hath reached it:
Now Ormandine, our bloody game begins,
Heads are our stakes, and there's but one can win.
Protect me heaven, what sudden strange eclipse do I behold
The golden sun that now smiled in my face,
Draws in his beams, and robes himself in black:
In what a dark veil is the clear azured sky!
You do begin to entertain me Ormandy,
But we'll have better welcome ere we part:
Ay, let your thunder come, we dread it not;
What send ye fire-drakes too to meet with us?
Your worst of horror is best welcome to me:
Your ministers rather invite me on, than like to bugbears
Fright me back again: more visitants of hell-bred sorcery?
I must needs through, or sink.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: There's nothing we can do,
Can quell the valour of this Christian knight.

sp.speaker: Orm.
sp.l: My fears divine this is the man,
By whom great Ormand falls: he's come unto the gates,
and now stick fast my sword, and we are yet secure:
So, in spite of all the tampering of your arts
We are got something near you now.
This is the gate; what have we here? A brazen pillar,
In it a golden sword, immured and riveted;
A golden tablet with inscriptions on't,
Let me discourse with you a little first.
Ormand be bold, secure, and free,
Revel in arts strong potency,
Till from the cold and Northern clime,
A knight post on the wings of time.
Ha, what's here? Till from the Northern clime,
A knight post on the wings of time.
A Northern knight! why that's myself:
Let's see a little farther.
Being lighted on Tartary's ground,
Of fame beloved by honour crowned.
I am arrived here in Tartary, a Northern knight,
And for my same and deeds of chivalry, with honour
Hath been crowned in prince's courts: a little farther yet.
From Brute descended, and his breast
Is with a sanguine cross be blessed.
I have enough; David of Wales from Brute descended is,
A Christian knight, that wears the sanguine cross,
That must dissolve this black enchantment here:
Come let me clutch thy temper in my hand,
Thus draw thee forth, and thus: will you not come?

sp.speaker: Orm.
sp.l: O you are not the man, ha, ha,
Fear vanish once again; go spirits, seize that knight,
And bring him straight.
Ormand and all laugh: spirits with fiery clubs, they fight.

sp.speaker: Orm.
sp.l: Knight, knight forbear,
In vain thy strokes are dealt against our power:
Thou mayst as well number those briny drops,
As cope with these, or scape with life, did not we pity thee;
spirits away.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Art not thou Ormandine?

sp.speaker: Orm.
sp.l: The same; thy friend and Ormandine.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: That head I come for, and must have't.
Runs at him with his sword, he puts it by with his wand.

sp.speaker: Orm.
sp.l: The body will not yet so part with it;
This is the Tartars cruelty not thine;
I know thy oath stands gauged to bring this head,
Or not return; thus shalt thou save thy oath,
Here shalt thou live, with Ormandine thy friend,
Here spend thy days, crowned with delight and mirth,
Pleasure shall be thy vassal to command,
With new inventions, fresh varieties,
And when thy dalliance would consort with love,
Queens shall enfold thee in their ivory arms,
Which to affirm, and give thee love and liking,
This waving of my wand above thy head,
Dissolves this horror, and does give thee cause
To change thy mind.

div.stage: The day clears, enchantments cease: sweet music.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: What alteration's here! your pardon mighty sir;
O let me never, never part from hence.

sp.speaker: Orm.
sp.l: Be master of your wish: come sit here by me,
I'll rape your care, and captivate your eye.

div.stage: Enter free excess, immodest mirth, delight, desire, Lust sated, and sickness, they dance; after the dance excess, delight, and desire embrace him to a lazy tune, they touch him, he falls into their arms, so carry him away.

sp.speaker: Orm.
sp.l: How happy now is Ormandine in this; I will no more
Credit the tablet I shall for ever rain, as now I do:
Eternity shall seal my habitation here,
The Britain knight is now within my power,
Charm hangs a drowsy rest upon his eyes,
and he shall sleep his youth to a full age.
As for the Arabian bird, and the proud tartar,
Revenge armed with destruction to them flies;
Who seeks my life, without my pity dies.

div.stage: Enter George armed, and clown with him.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Come on sir Suckabus, how do you like this alteration?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Nay, we are come to wear good cloth again, and we fill our bellies at other folks cost: marry we part with cracked crowns for our ordinaries. They that in the low country-garrisons kill men for three shillings a week, are punies to us; by that time I have served but half my time, I shall be able to play with all the fencers in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Leave your folly sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Leave your prating sir, and then we'll leave our livings both together.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Villain no more;
How pleasant is this place, how fresh and clear,
As when the last of April offers to sweet may
The pride and glory of the youthful spring,
The lovers coupling time! the farther that I go,
The more Elysium like it doth appear.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Good master let's go back again: I do not like this talking of Elysium; it is a place where good and honest men come in, and for mine own part, I am in the mind never to trouble it.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I think so too:
What's here the platform of a garden?
If that the sun robbed in his brightest glory,
Dazzle not mine eyes, it is the richest that I ever saw,
The paradise of some deity: — music too.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Ay, two tailors are a dancing for a buttered bun.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: List Suckabus, hearest thou no music?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I think I hear the horsehead and the tongues.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Most heavenly music, follow me close,
we'll see the guider of this heavenly sphere,
For sure no mortal owns it.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Pray sir let's back again, I have no mind to 't,
The sun shines so hot, I fear we shall have some rain.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: What's here, a wonder passed the other beauties far?
A brazen pillar, through whose impregnable body
Sticks a sword, a tablet, and inscriptions
Writ upon't, wonder falls on me!
Be'st thou enchantment, thou'rt the loveliest shape
That ever hell's art strove to tempt withal:
By your leave a little, it seems these are no secrets,
You're open breasted, I must know your mind:
We will not stand on doubts.

div.stage: He reads, pulls out the sword: thunder and lightning: a great cry within.
div.l: I am the man, for England, o you're welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Did not I tell ye? now shall I be roasted for devils, and my bones scorched into small-coals: where's the goodly weather that we had even now? where's the tongs and the tailors a dancing.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: Follow me slave, we'll in, and with this immured blade, that I set free, cut out my passage through the gates of horror: the enchantment's done, and George's happy fate some Christians may redeem from tyrant's hate.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Well, I were best run away, while I have legs to carry me: he's a good loving master, this same honest George, but he does lead me into more quarrels and dangers than all the roaring Davids in the world; but they are cowardly rascals, and I will stay no longer, my accounts are made even, and I will back again; hay day, they are at it.

div.stage: Thunder and lightning, devils run laughing over the stage: Tarpax with 'em.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Come, we are freed, let's now prepare his death, that being done, give welcome to him in confusion.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: O brave, that by his likeness and voice should be my sire Suckabus, 'tis he; I'll take acquaintance of him.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Who's that, the issue of my Calib?
Begone afore I'll follow.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: He sees me, and stays a purpose to talk with me: I will put on my mother's good face, and salute him: pray sir, hoping that the like is the same, father give me your blessing.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: What Suckabus? O let me kiss my boy:
A blessing on my princely son and heir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Thank you father, I have not known myself a long time: but now your blood royal begins to plump up my veins. Have you brought me never a letter from my mother Queen?

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: None my sweet son.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Why that shows now, she's in her pontificalities, in my kingdom after your decease, she never minds the sweet heir of her body, she casts me backward, as if I were unworthy to be prince of her joys: but I shall think on't.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Be patient son.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: You talk you know not what; have you no carriers in your kingdom?

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Yes, divers.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Is Hobson there, or Dawson, or Tom long?

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: I know not till I make inquiry.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Well, do so father;

And if you find 'em, send to me by 'em; they are honest men. Not a letter? Can Limbonia's Queen, and Duchess of Witchfordia so much forget herself, and that royal blood of hers, as not to send a letter to me?

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: List to me my son, and I'll show thee the cause,
Why so thy mother and our royal self sent not unto thee:
For hadst thou but obeyed the charge I left,
Just at the parting of thy mother from thee,
Thou hadst ere this been with us gentle boy,
Enthroned and honoured as thy mother is:
Welcomed with triumphs, shows, and fireworks:
Of what we want, we shall be furnished shortly.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
I would you had 'em, they'd give much content; o I do love those things a life i'faith. Have you any squibs
in your country? any green-men in your shows, and whizers upon lines, Jack pudding upon rope, or sis in fireworks? But pray father let me know why you did not send.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Then thus: I did not bid thee unsolace thy mind
Like a dejected low-begotten slave,
But revel, drink, laugh, and carouse, quarrel, and stab,
Game, wench, swear and curse, and if thy master offend thee,
Watch him asleep, and kindly cut his throat;
So doing, hadst thou long ere this come to us.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Forgive me this, and if the obeying of your will, will bring me to you, let me alone; I'll not be long from home: but father, what, no trick, no invention to make me famous ere I come to you? why, my mother could juggle as well as any hocus-pocus i'th' world, and shall I do nothing?

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Here, take this paper, learn these nine words in't;
At reading the first three, I will appear to thee,
To satisfy whatever thou demandest.
The virtue of the other three is this:
Look, in what place soe'er thou wish thyself,
Or company should meet thee to thy mind,
Speak but the middle three, 'tis done:
The best and last three words carry this property;
Which once rehearsed by thee,
Whom thou shalt please, shall straightways dote on thee,
Love thee entirely, nay, would die for thee,
If that in pity thou not comfortest them:
There's a jewel for my princely boy.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O sweet father, now thou lovest thy boy: but you know father, I never was so well learned, as to say God by my speed.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: The better, I would not have thee boy:
I will infuse that learning in thy brain,
That thou shalt read that whensoe'er thou please.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Pray read 'em over to me father.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: Observe the first three words: hulcha, pulch, palcha;
These three being spoken, I straight appear.
The next is Runio, rant, runto; then art thou
where thou please, and in what company,
The last and best Plagmanitis, squirtis, pampistis,
Thy love lies in thine arms.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: What a gift is here! I will cuckold the great Turk, love all his concubines, and lie with all over and over: I will beget a thousand of giants, fill the world full of bastards, march with an army royal of 'em into my kingdom, depose my father, and live like a monarch.

sp.speaker: Tarp.
sp.l: Come bring me a little on my way my son,
I'll tell thee braver things than these that thou shalt do.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: O my sweet father, what a man art thou!

div.stage: Enter George, bringing out Ormand and his friends.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: What is the cause, you ten times worse than devils,
That thus, like traitors, you deface and spoil
So fair a stamp as your great maker's is?
Why have you sold your endless bliss for bane?
Had they the hopes man has shining on them,
Worlds would not gain a life of thousand years,
And in those lives reign Kings and emperors,
Change those celestial joys you might have had:
Ever lost wretches, where's your power now?

sp.speaker: Orm.
sp.l: Vanquished by thee: that sanguine cross my tablet foretold,
Bloodsheds mine eyes for to behold it worn
And thou that Christian knight confounds my state:
Yet as thou honour'st what I fear to see,
As thou art hopeful of what's passed in me,
And as thou art a knight sworn to honour,
Grant me one small request.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: If thy request in honour's grant stands fair,
Give us the knowledge, we will see't performed,

sp.speaker: Orm.
sp.l: Then spare the lives of these two harmless men.
Which I secured by safety of my charms.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Are they not practised in thy horrid art?

sp.speaker: Orm.
sp.l: Christian no.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: The happier men: rise, we have no hate against ye.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Live still in honour, courteous Christian knight.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Now Ormandine quit this my grant ▪
with one request from me.

sp.speaker: Orm.
sp.l: 'Tis yours; say on.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: I crave the knowledge of your former being,
Before you found the path of your destruction.

sp.speaker: Orm.
sp.l: Know then ▪ that island seated in the main,
Whose crostic sides points to Barbary's kingdom,
Was I once Duke of, the nearest parts to it is this
Of Tartary, the other is Arabia, whose Kings disturbed
My peace and government: briefly, by flight we saved our
Lives; and to revenge those wrongs I practised on this art,
And since have lived scourges to both those Kings:
My tablet and pillar then erected, through whose hardness
Stuck that tempered blade; the riddles date on't did so strange appear,
That I thought ever, ever to live here.
And now you shall behold another Christian knight,
Sent from the tartar King, by oath enjoined to fetch my
Head, this did I deem the man, hath brought what you have,
My confusion, but missing of my fears, I entertained him fair,
Yet dreading still lest he might prove the man,
My art hung on his eyes these charms of sleep,
Which till I expiate, can never wake:
His name is David, and a Britain knight.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Ha, my brother! Prepare thee Ormand, this shall wake him.

sp.speaker: Orm.
sp.l: Hold, do not with crimson purple your white blade
With such a handsel: give me but leave to mount
Yond storied steps, and you shall see brave archers hit me sure:
Think not that I must live, would you life give,
Be good unto my friends: I fallen, take up your friend and hence.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Well to your fate: farewell.

sp.speaker: Orm.
sp.l: O are you aiming, 'twas time I came, you had
Fetched me else: so, so, we are met.
He that sells bliss, and would in this art shine,
At last shall pay for't, as did Ormandine.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: So, farewell Ormandine; wake David, wake.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Is the enchantment past? where is this fiend, this devil?
Ormandine, your charms no longer shall prevail on me.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: No more, they shall not noble Britain knight,
see who with joy embrace thee in his arms.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Brother of England, far-renown George,
Am I a second time enlarged by thee?
I shall pay time a death indebted to thy valour.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Do not engage so far,
Who knows what haps attend our next adventure?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Brother, where's Ormand?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Dead!

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: O I am lost, for ever lost and gone,
For ever bearing knightly arms again: o, o —

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Brave Britain knight with patience hear,
I'll tell o'er your own story.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Say on my oracle, I will attend.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: This sword you see is mine, enchantments done,
You wakened from death's sleep, think it not strange,
Ormand did declare before his death,
Your oaths adventure for to fetch his head:
By the Tartarian King, your oath shall be performed,
We'll take it off; these harmless men
That hither fled, only to save their lives,
Shall you get favoured of their King again;
I'll bear you company unto the King,
Where we again must part: you shall be further satisfied
In all what appears dark, I'll open as we ride.
Come brother David, we the world that range,
Must not admire at accidents or change.

div.head: Actus quartus.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: Come dear Leonides, my love's sole minion,
That like the powerful ruler of the fates,
Turns my restless necromantic charms
Into what form best fits thy appetite:
speak my Leonides, prithee smile, and speak it,
Could earth or hell invent a guard
To shield black crimes from direful punishment?
Walls are by wars strong engines razed and torn,
And center-reaching caverns of the earth,
Have oft been made the inhabitants sad graves:
But to build thee a stronger barracado,
I have fetched force from underneath the poles,
The slimy mists of dark Avernus' lake,
Cocytus pitchy steams are mixed with that,
And black compounded smoke the Cyclops send
From the foul sulphur of hot Aetna's forge,
All which I have compounded in a lump,
To make this isle obscure and tenebrous.
I'll tell thee friend, those furious giants that did war with heaven,
Had they effected their great enterprise,
Could not more glory in their usurpation,
Than I do in this masterpiece of art.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: True great Argalio,
Yet here I live as a reprieved prisoner,
In hope of life, sure of imprisonment,
Losing the benefit of life's repast.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: In what?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: In the grand loss of the all-pleasing light,
Without the which life is a misery too hard to be inflicted.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: Wrong not thy judgement with that fond opinion,
Night, why 'tis the proper sphere, the orb of pleasure;
When do those heirs of pleasure, Cupid's lords,
The active courtiers and attractive dames,
Choose to express their quintessence of mirth
In sports and revels, is't not in the night?
Night and the pleasures that she brings with her,
Shall make thee scorn day, as unnecessary:
My several spirits in an active dance
Shall now present themselves.

div.stage: Enter spirits, and dance; thunder and lightning.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Why are these terrors mixed with our delights?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: The angry heavens with common destiny, thunder,
Reprove my sports.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: As they'd oppose my sins:
sp.stage: Enter Leopides with father and sister.
sp.l: See, see where those poor souls,
Their murdering hands pulled from the mortal
Motion of their flesh, come back to give
The ferryman his hire, I am behind hand in that
Fatal debt: but now in spite of his black churlish oar,
We'll waft ourselves unto the hoped shore.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: Correct thy fear affrighted fantasy
Against these fond illusions, see they are vanished;
Come unto pleasures turn, they but abuse thy thoughts.

sp.speaker: Spirit
sp.l: O great Argalio, call thy ablest charms,
Never had art more need to help her mistress:
Three bold adventurous knights prepare themselves
To ruin thee ▪ and thy Leonides:
Aurela, Queen of this unhappy kingdom,
Has given her best advice to further them.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: Be careful of your charge,
Down to the infernal vaults, call up
The legion of the lower world, and throw
Hell's vengeance on them:
Come my Leonides, away with fear,
Should these charms fail, which to mistrust were poor,
My art should help thee with ten thousand more.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Sure I have lost mine eyes, or else am walked
Into eternal darkness: I have read how wise
Ulysses saw the under world, conversed with bold
Achilles and the Greeks, and then returned alive
To earth again, but fables help but weakly,
Imitate what really I feel I have lost,
My fellows in this endless night; till now
Their voyees kept me company. Ho Denis, Denis.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Here, here.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Where art thou man?

sp.speaker: Den.
sp.l: Wading through fire, and buffetting with air.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: Where's Patrick?

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Here, here.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: Where's my noble Spaniard?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Here, my friend.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: We all came several ways then?

sp.speaker: Den.
sp.l: But a worse than I have ventured, never
Man set foot to: first through a lake that
Lybia's deserts yield not more hot contagions,
Venom that has struck confused terror
Throughout all my limbs, and pierced my armours
Closure, then was I fain to interpose my shield,
Betwixt me and that ponderous weight, that fell,
As if some castles ruins had fallen down,
To crush me into nothing.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: Mulciber like I walked through fire,
And as the salamander bathed in the flames,
Winding his body in a stream of sulphur,
So the devouring heat encompassed me.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: But I had music in my passage friends,
The whistler and the screech-owl joined their songs,
The boding ravens made the consort up,
And with their multitudes pressed me to earth;
But here the air breathes cold and gently on us:
Is not yond light? or being enured to darkness,
Have not our eyes forgotten their faculties?
'Tis light; what's here, a pillar, and a tablet on't?
The lively taper, which not only clears our eyes,
So long invaded with Cimmerian mists, but gives
Us light, by viewing this inscription, thereby
For to unfold this dark aenigma.
Read Denis.

lg.head: Denis reads.
lg.l: Read, and wonder, you that be not be
Not born to end this prodigy.
The golden fleece, which Jason sought,
In emblem must be hither brought,
The flower de Luce and harp must join,
Before the riddle you untwine.
Iberia's earth must yield a knight,
That must extinguish this great light.
By the same water must be found,
That born was on unvenomed ground.
A gallion helmet, that must hold
The water that these charms unfold;
That done, this land resumes her rest,
And all enchantments here depressed.

div.l: Either my genius flatters my best thoughts,
Or else we three were born to consummate
This great adventure.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: 'Tis most plain, Spain gave me birth,
The golden fleece mine arms,
The figure of that prize which Jason brought,
And to make perfect the inscription,
Here is a helmet framed in Normandy,
Which I have worn in all my travails since.

sp.speaker: Den.
sp.l: No more of doubts; Argalio and Leonides
Prepare to meet your ruin, your all potent charms,
Methinks I see them fly from room to room,
Searching the caverns and obscurest vaults
To hide their guilty heads from vengeance:
And this strong charm, once thought invincible,
When it shall vanish like an idle dream,
Their confidence will plague their conscience more,
Than if they had mistrusted it before.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: No more delays, but boldly let's assail,
Our cause is good, and justice must prevail.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: It clears, it clears:
What does thy art avail thee,
Thou that hast said for to obscure the sun,
Where are they fled? hide thyself now Argalio,
and hide my errors with thee, they are vain,
As my beliefs are, that thou hast a knowledge
Above my mischiefs: horse us on the clouds,
For naught else can prevent our imminent ruin.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: Art thou yet doubtful, unbelieving boy?
Remember the large stretched thoughts
I have employed to arm thee, could I cause
Darkness? could my powerful art hide the
Bright sun in his most royal progress?
And shall it be confined by these opposers?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I cannot have a faith in these delusions:
Let me despair and die; here is a sword
Can quickly ease my torments, and set free
A burdened conscience: how freely will my spirit
Greet the air of hell's black kingdom:
There the Thracian sits, hard by the sullen
Waters of black Styx, fingering his lute;
To hear whose pleasing strains, hell's ministers
Forget their offices, the wearied souls their torments,
The whole vault resounds his echoes;
Thither will I hie, and lay my troubled head
Upon his lap, and he shall charm me
Into endless slumbers.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: Hold brainsick man, look up for thy safety;
Seest thou this throne by sable spirits born,
In it we'll mount, so unbelieved a height,
Earth shall appear an atom to thine eye:
Thou shalt view Cynthia in her silver sphere,
Couched by Aurora on her rosy bed; and make
The sun-god jealous of your loves:
We'll progress over the celestial orbs,
Thence to the winds, and view the hollow cave,
Where Aeol fetters up the unruly brood;
Then by descensions pleasing to our thoughts,
We'll take survey of Neptune's watery rule,
Ride o'er the bosom of the ocean
On crooked dolphins,
Amphion like, striking a well tuned harp,
And then to th' earth again.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Thou hast given me a new life,
I feel a new unwonted joy assail me,
And all my sorrows vanish like those clouds,
That even but now environed us with darkness.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: Mount then my son, and as we reach the sky,
My spirits shall salute us with sweet bays,
Jove shall bow down his head to hear their lays,
And wish himself commander of their skill:
Will this delight thee?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: O my happy friend.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: Earth, nor her strongest hold shall not secure 'em.

sp.speaker: Den.
sp.l: O act of wonder, we in vain pursue:
Look how they raise themselves unto the clouds:
O had I wings but to o'ertake
The villain, devil, enchanter.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha; fools to imagine you could wrong Argalio,
I pity you, or else my powerful hand
Should crush you into air:
Stand, and admire, whilst we ascend a height
Above your weak thoughts.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: Yet are we happy, though they scaped
Our justice, that we have freed
The country from contagion. The people
Find this benefit already;
And hark, with shouts applaud this act
Of wonder: let's to the Queen,
And fully give relations of all these accidents,
Then are we free for other warlike deeds.
Virtue should still be active, apt to right
Those which are wronged, and good deeds to requite.

div.head: Actus quintus.
div.stage: Enter Suckabus with bread and meat in his hand.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Ah sirrah, the world is pretty well amended with me now, thanks to my kingly father, and his charms, 'twas time for me to leave the domineering rascal, and his beggarly crew of wanderers, grooms I may term them, for if they had been knights they would never have used a prince amongst 'em so. I have travailed five times through the world, and not a town, city, or Burrough in England but I carried the marks on my shoulders to show for't. The best days that ever I saw with 'em, was when we hired Charles wain, and rid about the elements, that was the best twelve days journey that e'er I had: and I remember we had good lodging at the twelve signs, and nobly used, for they would not take one penny, and to say the truth we had no money to give: but how we got up, or how the devil we got down again I know not: and then we fell to our old course again, to kill every one that we met: which course I not liking, in regard we must fight for our victuals, I begged this charm of my father, where hearing of a famous castle of Brandron's, and what a brave house he kept for victuals, I out with my spell, and straight wished me there; which being no sooner uttered, but a hawk or a buzzard flew betwixt my legs, mounted me in the air, and set me down here, where I find whole oxen, boiled in a pottage-pot will hold more water than the Thames, and now having pretty well stuffed my pannier, I'll e'en take a he sleeps. nap, and so wish myself somewhere else.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: How weary am I with this foraging,
Yet cannot find my hunted prey come in:
Have I a truce granted to a fruitful kingdom,
And her chief city, not a mile from hence
Upon condition I should spare his city,
Self, and people, to have my quick provision hunted
Into my iron nets, and do they break and baffle thus?
Is bear and lion food too good for me?
Why then I see I must take pains to march,
And with my iron mace, pound, pash, and mortar them
And city too: o the net is fallen,
'Tis well you keep your league.
How now, what scarecrow's that?
A sleeping dormouse in my castle walls: how got he in?
I have no other porter than myself,
And through the keyhole sure he could not crawl;
How or which way should this small spy get in?
Sirrah awake, or with one fillip of my iron mace,
I'll send eternal sleep to seize on thee:
Awake you dog.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Ay, ay, you say very well father, 'tis true indeed,
And then watch him asleep, and kindly cut his throat.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: How? cut my throat? I shall prevent ye slave:
Wren of deformity awake I say.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: I hear a rumbling noise, I'll e'en pack up my trinkets, and begone: o lord what will become of me! I have wished myself to have my brains beat out.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: What art thou worm?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: An't please you sir, I am a prince, a sweet young prince, my father's name is Tarpax, prince of the grisly North, my mother's name was Calib, Queen of Limbonia, and Duchess of Witchfordia.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Perish thy father and thy mother, as thyself shall:
Slave how got'st thou in?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: I flew over the castle wall.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Bird of the devil, where's your wings to fly?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: If you will give me leave, you shall see me fly the same way back again.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: No my fine pigeon, I will clip your wings:
Come to my cauldron, come I'll see how finely you can
Flutter there, it reeks and bubbles, there
I'll plunge thee in, there shalt thou play my pig.
Till thou art fine, soft, plump, and tender sod ▪
And then I'll pick thy bones my dainty bird.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: O lord, what shall become of me? boiled, oh lord, the very terror of that word, hath thrust the charm quite from my head, that charm would save me; o sweet father now or never help me, and save a prince from boiling, a boyld prince is his meat else.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Dispatch my bird.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: O sweet father, now, now, now I go else,
Boiled: o the thought of that word: oh I ha't,
Sweet father I thank thee,
Has put that charm into my head
Shall make 'em all in love with me:
Now I care not.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Why when I say?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Splagnalis squirtis p●mpistis.
The giant in a maze lets fall his club.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Ha! the beams of wonder shoots into mine eyes,
And love and pity hath surprised my heart.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: O sweet father, now he's mine sure, and I will domineer.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: The morning's majesty doth not so fresh break forth,
When she doth usher the altitionate from forth his bed
Of spices, here to shine: how were mine eyes deluded,
My sweet boy, when that I thought
Deformity hung here? for which upon my knees
I beg thy gracious pardon, and with submission,
And contrition, do desire that favour,
But to kiss thy foot.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: My foot? no you shall kiss somewhere else,
My backside of this hand is yours.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I merit not that favour, heavenly boy.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Go too, I'll have my will, my hand is yours I say.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: And for that hand my whole heart is thy slave;
Demand, and take the life of Brandron.
Then say, my dotage darling, canst thou love me?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: As well as I love roast beef:
Hast any victuals love? I am a hungry.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Enough, my dainty boy; the banquet of the gods,
To which flew Saturn, once in thirty years,
Tasteth not there of more delightsome cates,
Than I'll have for my love: come in my boy,
Walk with me hand in hand,
Thou shalt not ask, but have thy full demand.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Brothers, you are welcome all to Brandron's castle.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Not Brandron nor his castle
Long shall bear that name.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: A strong and sumptuous habitation.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Too good a palace for a tyrant's rain.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: What, shall we knock, and rouse the monster up?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let's walk the round, and take a view
Of this strong castle first; happily we may find
A passage in, for to surprise him
Ere he think of us; let's strike upon occasion,
But advantage, in law of arms, deserves this
Hateful traitor.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: Your counsel we'll allow, on, let be so:
Come gentlemen, let's walk, but not too near
The castle pray, least treasons bounty
Should drop down upon us.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: What if we find no entrance,
And he refuse our summons, and not come?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: That cannot be, we then might starve the fiend;
His food is daily hunted to these nets,
And once a day we are sure to meet with him:
Then let us careful pass about these walls.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: How likest thou Brandron, and his castle boy?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: As I am a prince,
I was never better pleased in all my life.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Music to Brandron's ear that thou art so.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Now you talk of music, will you hear me sing?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: A contradiction to thy will, were poison
To my thoughts: on my soul's harmony.

lg.head: Clown sings.
lg.l: I have a love, as white as a raven,
Excelling for blackness the snow,
She will scold, scratch, and bite
Like a fury or spright,
And yet she was counted no shrew.
The hair of her head was like cobbler's thread,
Which sow-haires do draw through so,
Her legs on each foot
Is so swollen with the gout,
That my love is not able to go.
Her face bears a front, like to wear waterspout.
Which brought was from thence by great cunning,
With a mill in her bum,
That did roar like a drum,
Which did set her fair nose still a running.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Orion, that o'erstrode the dolphin with his harp,
Ne'er song nor played such chanting melody:
Thou hast made me drowsy love with thy sweet air.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: I carry air at both ends of my pipe,
But this is the sweeter: come what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Walk with thy Jove, my lovely Ganymede,
And once a day survey my castle round,
Then will I play with these thy silken locks,
Kiss that sweet Venus' mole upon thy cheek,
And smell unto thy sweet Sabean breath,
Then will we walk and view my silver fountain,
And my silver swans, whom next to thee,
I take most pleasure in.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: I like that fountain very well,
And the three swans that swims about it:
I was wishing for a goose-pie made
Made of one of 'em but the tother day.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Little dost thou know what those swans be.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Why, what are they?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: List, and I'll tell thee:
Those swans are daughters to the King of Macedon,
Whom I surprised, and kept within my castle,
Till at the length, so scorched with love's hot flames ▪
That Brandron needs must die, if not enjoy:
So thinking to deflower 'em one by one,
Each by her prayers converted to a swan,
And flew for safety in my golden fountain,
And there for ever shall my Leda's birds
Remain, unharmed by Brandron, or any.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: O monstrous, I have heard indeed that wenches have turned pretty coneys, ducks, or pigeons; but swans, oh brave: come whither shall we go now love?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Up to the promontory top of my fair castle,
There take thy pleasure of the morning's air,
Breathed from Aurora's care the sun doth wake,
From thence to banquet upon lions' hearts,
I'll feast the high and strong, my Ganymed:
Come let us mount, pleasure's to us a toy,
My happiness consists in thee my boy.

sp.speaker: Den.
sp.l: As yet we cannot find a fitting place,
Where we may make a breach for entrance.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: What shall we rouse him then?

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: A little stay, we have not yet begirt the castle walls,
The time of his approach will not be long,
For all his iron nets are stored you see.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I long to see, and grapple with the monster.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Here's no man here but hath the same desire.
Come let us walk.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Where art thou love?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Here, here, as close as beggary to a prodigal,
I'll never forsake ye I'll warrant.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: 'Tis well; now we have attained the highest top: ha!

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: What's the matter sir?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: See, see, six straggling spies, wand'ring fugitives
Are lurking about my walls to make a breach,
And steal my swans away; but I will down,
And with my iron mace send 'em a welcome,
That their powder bones shall seem a pastime
For the wind to play with.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Go to love, no more such words,
No more I say, I know 'em well enough.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Dost thou my love?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Yes, and I am afraid you will know 'em to your
Cost: there's not a man of these, but is able to cope
With a whole army.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: You were best tell me I lie:
Have you not heard of seven roaring boys,
That made such a damnable thunder through the world,
Making gallimafries of all came in their way?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: O the Christian curs, what then?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: These are six of 'em, and I'm afraid the seventh,
And that's my master, George of England.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Are these the men? beshrew me heart
The largeness of their fame makes Brandron shrug.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Do not you fear for all this;
What will you say if I betray all these champions to ye,
And bring 'em all unarmed unto your mercy?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I cannot love thee dearer if thou dost,
But I am loath to venture thee my love.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Take you no care for that, I'll do't,
Give me the keys, and then when i have got them in
Unarmed, if we cannot make our parties good with 'em,
Would you were hanged i'faith.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Go and be fortunate, I long till thou returnest.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: There is no hope of entrance till he comes.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Shall we obscure ourselves till then,
Or face the monster at his coming out?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Obscure, no brother Andrew, here's not a man of us
But singly dares both meet and cope with him:
But soft, I hear the gates unlock,
Each stand upon his guard, the giant comes.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Who this?
This the mighty Brandron?

sp.speaker: Den.
sp.l: If black enchantments do not blind mine eyes,
I well should know that habit and that person:
Send me your judgements, know you not that face?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: 'Tis Suckabus, our brother George's man.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: You are not deceived sir, I'm the very same.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: What Suckabus?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Gentlemen, 'tis no wonder for us that are champions to meet at though world's end: my master's i'th castle.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: 'Tis as I tell ye; we saw ye out of a window look about the castle walls, and laughed heartily at ye, and so did the ladies too.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: How, ladies?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Yes faith ladies: my master hath killed the giant, a foul great lubberly knave he was I'm sure a that: we had much ado with him ere he fell: but now have we the bravest life with the ladies, we do nothing but dance with 'em all day long. You must come up unto my master presently.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: With all our hearts;
Lead the way good Suckabus.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Nay not so hasty neither: my master doth earnestly desire you, that you would deliver all your weapons to me, for fear of frighting the ladies; there must no sign of a soldier now appear, all must be lovers that do enter there.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: With all our hearts; take 'em, and lead the way.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Why now it is as it should be;
I'll bring you sweet linen and water to refresh you, and then into your pantables, and pump up the ladies.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Excellent Suckabus.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha; how happy am I in this faithful boy?
I have beheld through a chink, the knights
Brought in unarmed and weaponless:
O my prosperous politician how I love thee:
These were the knights whom I did ever fear,
And now I have 'em all mine own but one:
O here comes my boy; the news, the news?
My eyes best object; what are they springed my love?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Ay, they are my own, fast locked in a pitfold:
But I have stranger news to tell thee than this.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Say on, we are secure from fear and danger now.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: After my slight had fetched 'em in unarmed,
And caged my birds fast under lock and key,
I went to fetch some weapons that I left
Behind me at the gate porch: where peeping
Through a keyhole, by more chance I spied my master
George of England, prancing his steed about the walls.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: What's he the seventh?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Ay, and the veriest kill-cow of 'em all,
These are but very punies to him.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Go and betray him as thou didst the rest.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Nay soft, some wiser than some: he's no such fellow as ye take him for; he may hear me, but he'll see me hanged ere he trust me; for indeed I have been so trusty to him, that he'll be sure to truss, if he catch me.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I will not venture thee ▪ come, let's to these knights,
If they will yield unto our fair demands,
And by that Christian power they do adore,
Swear fealty and faithful love to us,
To fight our battles, and our champions prove,
'Gainst those that shall oppose our might and power,
We are their friends, and they shall live in favour;
but if denial breath from ones lip,
He and the rest shall perish instantly:
Follow me love.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Through black enchantments, misbelieving men,
Wild beasts and monsters, and through death himself,
Hath George of England made his passage, to the desire
Of my longing thoughts; and by my
Tedious travails have I now obtained,
And here I am arrived, where ends my fame,
Or deeper shall insculp my honoured name.
The castle bears a foul usurped title,
Which I will read out of the tyrant's heart,
And back deliver injured honours due,
Or die in the attempt.
A rich and stately building ▪
How fast 'tis riveted into the rock,
As if the sure foundations and the walls were one,
How gaind'd the monster such a policy to vanquish,
And still hold it as his own?
I have no other way but one, and this is it,
This sword must play the pioneer for me,
Which through Brandron's plaited coat of brass,
Shall cut his passage to his heart:
And thus I ring death's alarm at his gate.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Ha, what harebrained frantic urchin have we there?
Dost come to meet the crows and chatting pies?
They'll make a banquet of thy carcase:
Reserve your smooth-faced brow to play with ladies,
Begun I say, and do not make reply,
For if thou urge me to a porter's pains,
The strong nerved Cyclops, who by ponderous weight,
Forged out the gates of steel, ne'er laid such strokes,
〈◊〉 I will on thy childish burgonet.
〈…〉 thou seest I'm pitiful.
〈…〉 be accepted at thy hand by such as fear
thy bugbear terms, were thy deeds as much:
Therefore descend, and to my hands deliver up the keys,
With it those virgins, undeflowred and wronged,
The daughters to the King of Macedon,
Or by the sacred cross of Christendom,
Under whose banner George of England fights,
I'll pitch thy head upon the wall thou standst,
And traitor like thy hateful limbs beside.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: O, we have heard of you before, but since you are so hot ▪
I'll fetch a julip for to cool your blood,
You shall be fought, and fought, and fought with too:
Betake you to your tools, that valour tries,
For never till now you played your master-prize,

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: I do accept it: Brandron in this alone
Do I find thee honourable: mean time,
I will prepare to entertain them.

div.stage: Enter Brandron aloft, with all the champions and clown.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Hollow once more, look up and see,
If these thou conquerst, than thou cop'st with me,
But not before: nay, never start, I know thou knowest 'em well,
You never so strange were, as you must be now:
I keep those bonds which yoked your amities,
And I have broke those bonds: these, once whate'er they were,
Are now my subjects, and all sworn to fight
In Brandron's quarrel, be it wrong or right.
Ay, and to die in't: question them I pray.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Amazement throws his wonders on my head:
Brother resolve me, is it so, or no?
I see you're prisoners to his power and will,
But let me know the means that makes you so,
Lives there no foul enchantment in this place?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Brother not any.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: Monster, I know thou tookest 'em not in fight;
The meanest of them them there that stands by thee,
But with the quick flames of his resolution,
Had scorched thee into ashes: give reason then
How this should come to pass?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: One of you tell him, if you please you may.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: We all arrived at one court, the Macedonian Kings,
And coming hither in his wrongs behalf,
Met with your hellborn Suckabus,
Who was before by Brandron entertained;
No sooner we approached the castle here,
And made a gentle walk about the walls,
But running to us with great signs of joy, that slave
Came to us, told us yourself was here,
And how the mighty Brandron by your hand was slain.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha; o my dainty boy, stand near my love,
Here's none dares injure thee.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Look how master George on footback frowns
On me, but I care not.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Further he told us 'twas your fair request,
Having sweet music and fair ladies with you,
We should come in unarmed and weaponless:
We being joyful, thinking truth he spoke,
Were all betrayed, and so to Brandron led,
And so our lives were granted, on condition,
His wrong or right to guard against the world.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Brood of the devil thou shalt pay for this.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Thy worst, I defy thee.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: What we must fight then?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Brother we must.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Well then, what remedy?
But tell me Brandron, ere we begin,
Since thou hast set this quarrel on our heads,
Shall I have fair and single opposition?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Champion thou shalt.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Seal it with your oath, and then 'tis firm.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Why by the Ethiopes stamp, yond burning ball,
I vow; and this I furthermore will promise,
That each several combatant shall bear several arms;
And to thyself, from our rich armoury,
Weapons I'll send complete, although mine enemy:
Here, take the keys, my boy, and see each weapon fitted
both for him and them: mean time, hear will we sit
Spectators of their deeds: o they are met.

div.stage: Enter champions severally, armed; weapons brought for George.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: You're welcome to our castle: I'm your first man brother

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: You are welcome.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: For Brandron, and his right.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: For England, and the Britons do I fight.
Brother you're mine, your quarrel is not good.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: What I have lost, then call it Brandron's blood.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: You are noble. Come the next.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: That's I for Brandron.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: I stand for Scotland now.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: You have won it fairly; take it as your own.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: You're welcome home.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: And I am glad it is so well fallen out.

div.stage: Each fight their several combats: George overcomes them all: Brandron stamps.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Let us unite our brotherhoods again.
You are welcome to your liberty.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: We joy to see't.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: There are the keys ▪ enter, and seize on Brandron.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Am I betrayed?

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Each hath the best done to defend your state,
Then yield thee to the mercy of our brother.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: First will I head long throw me from this tower,
And dash my brains 'gainst the craggy rocks,
That murmurs at the fall of Brandron:
No, Christian slaves, you shall not write
Your glories in my blood, to say,
The mighty Brandron fell by you:
Brandron wins glory to himself to yield,
And thus will conquer Brandron in the field,

div.stage: He beats out his own brains.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: One ruin ends for to begin another:
Enter the castle, seek the slave his man.
And give his guerdon for his treachery.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: That will we do; follow me Anthony.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: What drum is that? let's in, and stand upon our guard,

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: It is our friend, the King of Macedon.
That comes to gratify our victory.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: We'll greet him with a token of our loves.

div.stage: Enter the King, drum, colours, and soldiers.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I come in loving quest of you, brave Christian knights,
Who since your absence from our mournful court,
In this adventure took in our behalfs,
Fear made us doubt your safety and your lives:
Wherefore resolved, in quittance of your loss,
More than the wrongs I did sustain before,
Made us thus change our mournful black for steel,
And armed with dread less danger of our lives,
Came thus resolved, to fight, and die for you.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: You have outdone us in your noble mind:
Brother of England, embrace this aged King:
And reverend sir, do you the like by him;
This the seventh, which in this enterprise,
Redeemed us from the hateful hands of treachery.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I joy to see such worth abound in man,
May honours spring send garlands for thy brow,
And victory still dwell on thy triumphant arm:
I glory in your conquest.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Which glory once more shines upon thy head;
The hateful monster, that usurped so long,
And kept poor Tenopas in dread and awe,
Hath justice from his own hand done himself,
And you are honour of your loss again:
Therefore reserve it as our loving deed,
And wear it as our favour.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: You so enrich me with your love and bounty,
My life and kingdom is too poor to thank ye.
Were I assured of my daughter's lives,
I were ascended to my height of joy.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Of that these gentlemen can more resolve ye.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: We never knew, nor saw no ladies there.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Why then they are dead:
Sweet peace rest with their souls.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: As you are gentlemen use not a prince so hardly: what I have done was merely out of love; because I would have you stayed men, men of biding, to be forth coming, though not every hour coming forth: master George, for my Queen mother's sake, that killed your father and mother, and kept you in a cave, have compassion upon me.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Dispatch, and hang the slave.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: What shall I do now? I have been calling to my father for help, and he does nothing, but stands and laughs at me, and will not put my charm in my head.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Nay come away good Suckabus.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Which is the King of Macedon, I pray?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I am my friend, but cannot save thy life,
Because thou didst betray these gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: I do beseech thy kingly worship to save my life, and
I will bring you where your daughters are.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Thou pourest fresh blood into our empty veins,
And melts the snow that lay upon my heart:
Victorious knights, as much renowned for pity,
As for valour, upon my aged knees I beg the life
Of this condemned wretch.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: You must not kneel: upon condition that thou dost perform,
Thy words, we will not only give thee life,
But guard on thee with rich rewards, and love:
But if thy fear delude us, hoping to save thy life —

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Why you may hang me then, that's all the care I take.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: And wilt thou bring me to my daughter's friend?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: Come follow me, I'll lead you a dance.
Three whitings they cockle, and set in their luddle,
Sing bay cock without a comb, sing cock a doodle.
Look you, do you see those three swans? these swans were once the daughters, ducks and darlings to the King of Macedon.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Those were the swans that in the fountain lived:
Did not I tell you what this slave would do?
Dispatch and hang him straight.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I do beseech ye spare him;
And noble knights, thus for to let you know,
I do give faithful credit to his words;
Hear me relate what once my daughters told me;
The eldest having privilege of birth,
Came to me first for to relate her dream,
And asked me if I could interpret it;
I answered, as I had small faith in dreams,
So I had less knowledge to expound the meaning.
Yet went she on; I dreamt, said she, my sisters and myself
Were playing round about your golden fountain,
When suddenly we all three were surprised,
By a fierce savage and inhumane monster,
And as his flaming lust did us pursue,
We turned to swans, and in the fountain flew.
As she related so did both the rest,
And all three had one dream.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: I'll assure you, the giant that is dead told me the self same tale, and how he would have done something to 'em, but having three eels by the tail they slipped out of his fingers, and flew like swans into the golden fountain.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: This doth confirm it more: o my swans, my girls!
Come shall we sing our requiem together?
And at the stretching out your silver wings,
Your aged father falls and dies with you.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Take comfort, royal Macedon, as heaven for to preserve
Their honours, changed their shapes it may be pleased
For to restore again, for after prescripts to believing men,
And would you but become —

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: In that I'll interrupt ye: hold I pray,
Let me embrace you all; nay, take sure hold:
Though clouds of darkness did my clear shine smother,
I am converted to each here a brother.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: A happy conversion.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Blessed Macedon, thou hast sent a gift to heaven,
Born upon angels wings;
And is by us on earth here ratified,
Which without this could never have been done.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: O father, father, happy are we now.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: My blessing on my swans, my new found joys:
We all are Christians now.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: O happy state!

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: Each lady doth deserve a monarch's bed.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.l: Renowned knights, may we desire to know,
Which of you are unmarried?

sp.speaker: An. De. Pat.
sp.l: We are.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Then here's three ladies, take 'em to your beds.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: George highly honours aged Macedon.

sp.speaker: 3 Knig.
sp.l: But can the lady's love accord with us?

sp.speaker: 3 Lad.
sp.l: Most willingly.

sp.speaker: 3 King.
sp.l: We thus then seal our contracts.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Which thus we ratify:
Sit with the brides, most noble Macedon,
And since kind fortune sent such happy chance,
We'll grace your nuptials with a soldier's dance.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: True noble knights, how am I honoured in you?

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.l: No more good Macedon: pray lead the way,
We'll see your nuptial rites,
That task once done,
We must abroad for fame of Christendom.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
